author: timbeiko
content:
+1. Another way to view this is that right now 100% of the excess revenue in txn fees is captured by miners. 1559 lowers the amount that is captured by miners (by burning the base fee) and gives that amount back to ETH holders via deflation. To what extent it is lowered is not clear yet, but we can assume it will be substantial and that "mining economics" will be closer to what they were 1-2 years ago where the block reward is the large majority of revenue. 

Burning the fees is necessary to get 1559's UX benefits because we need a way to gauge demand for block space, which we use the base fee to do. If the base fee is not burnt, then miners can influence it, which makes it useless as a gauge of demand.

author: timbeiko
content: Also, if too many miners find it unprofitable to mine under 1559, because their costs are closer to `block reward + txn fees` than stricly `block reward`, then we will see miners mine other chains, which will lower the difficulty, making it attractive for other miners to come in, and we'll settle on another equilibrium.

author: timbeiko
content:
Responding to this quickly. Under 1559, we'll likely see the mempool being mostly empty (vs. mostly full as today), which creates more competitions between miners to include txns in the next block. If a miner mines an empty block, they are basically forfeiting their txn fee revenue (from tips) to the miner of the next block. 

Re: spam, I'm not sure I understand. 1559 makes on-chain spam somewhat less likely given that everyone (miners incl.) has to pay the base fee, whereas now miners can include txns with 0 fees on chain.

author: misterx7348
content: Why would there be tips if blocks are empty?

author: misterx7348
content: tips are for transactions that someone wants to have processed quickly right? (e.g. when blocks are full and you want to be included earlier)

author: misterx7348
content: i must be missing something

author: timbeiko
content: Yes: we expect all transactions to have tips.

author: timbeiko
content: Most transactions will have a small tip (e.g. 1-2 gwei), and some that need to be processed urgently will have larger ones.

content: I think <@489256758989029405> was concerned that if 1559 is ready before Berlin he would like to see it go out *without* waiting on Berlin, which I believe is why we haven't implemented or specced out 2718.

author: .vbuterin
content: Especially given that, as I have mentioned many times, we _already_ have the equivalent of 2x blocks for a period of 5 minutes once a week, due to PoW block time Poisson randomness alone

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: (I don't think either are a problem, but that is how I understand the opposition)

author: .vbuterin
content: right, but as you said, there's no evidence of any kind of superlinear processing time within a single block

author: sky.cactus
content:
If I was running things (which I most definitely am not) I would suggest we either:
1. Start prepping 1559 hard fork.
2. Start speccing and implementing 2718 into 1559 branches.

content: I am working on this EIP for more than a year now. And we did much more than for any EIP just to make people happy

author: abdel.stark
content: That's enough IMO

author: sky.cactus
content: I would *rather* launch 1559 with 2718 regardless of Berlin timing.

author: abdel.stark
content: Yep I prefer (2) as well

author: abdel.stark
content: And we have the code ready. Let me check with people working on Geth implementation

author: abdel.stark
content: If they are ready to ship with 2718

author: sky.cactus
content: That is all correct.  However, 1559 doesn't *necessarily* have to launch before Berlin.  The *idea* is that if 1559 is ready before berlin, then we HF with that.  The *hope* is that we can get into a cadence of "have branches for everything and schedule a HF whenever a thing is done" or something.

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, I'm pretty pessimistic that we could get 1559 out before Berlin.

author: .vbuterin
content: Wait I thought 1559 is definitely going after Berlin?

author: sky.cactus
content: Some people believe that.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: There are some who don't think that we should be holding up finished work for Berlin.

author: .vbuterin
content: Meaning, EIP 1559 is finished work, and so we should Just Do It already?

author: sky.cactus
content: It turns out, in a leaderless organization people disagree and predicting the future is hard.  ðŸ˜›

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, essentially.

author: .vbuterin
content: I'm gonna defer to <@!552133098075193354> there....

author: sky.cactus
content: We have historically had a tendency to try to plan a hard fork, and then do the work to launch that HF.  There are some core devs would would rather do the work, and when it is done schedule a HF.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is an attempted solution to the current Berlin problems we have been having (taking forever, done stuff keeps getting kicked out of it, etc.).

author: abdel.stark
content: Well, what are we waiting for ? I mean if we are ok with skipping this extra performance testing that we never did before.

author: sky.cactus
content: Either 2718 integration or commitment to release 1559 before Berlin.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unfortunately, they seem to be mutually exclusive.

author: sky.cactus
content: The people that want to "launch when done" don't want to integrate 2718+1559 unless it is necessary.

author: sky.cactus
content: The people that want to "launch after Berlin" will naturally require 2718 integraton.

author: sky.cactus
content: My vote would be we spec out and integrate 2718.  I personally think we should do that even if we launch before Berlin.

author: abdel.stark
content: Can we present 1559 as a "normal" EIP next ACD ? I think it is time to stop considering it special and have a special treatment

author: sky.cactus
content: You can try.  I think any talk that isn't about Berlin is unlikely to get much traction.

author: abdel.stark
content: Hmm. I will see with <@!552133098075193354> if it is worth trying

author: misterx7348

author: sky.cactus
content: "Miners mining empty blocks" is a very common proposed attack vector, which is why it is mentioned in just about every document.  ðŸ˜„

author: misterx7348
content: Alright empty blocks do not go up anymore afaik, don't know why nobody has referred to this doc before.

author: misterx7348
content: Its very easy to neutralize that argument.

author: misterx7348
content: I cite

author: misterx7348
content: *Should a miner attempt to execute this attack, we can simply increase the elasticity multiplier (currently 2x) which requires they have even more hashing power available before the attack can even be theoretically profitable against defectors.*

author: misterx7348
content: I didn't know about that, and nobody brought it up when I mentioned empty blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect because this debate comes up weekly, and often with some of the same people, so it is hard to tell who has and who hasn't been linked toarious resources.

author: misterx7348
content: The discussion ends at increasing the elasticity multiplier

author: misterx7348
content: Its very simple

author: misterx7348
content: I personally can't stand behind the point of empty blocks being a problem

author: misterx7348
content: also 51% attack is a non issue, its only a issue when 50% of hash goes nicehash - btc goes up 10x and eth dumps 50%

author: misterx7348
content: as rn theres 3% nicehashable

author: sky.cactus
content: Keep in mind, elasticity multiplier would require a hard fork.  A trivial one, bet does require coordination.

author: misterx7348
content: Isn't it included in EIP1559 / already existing?

author: sky.cactus
content: So timetable would be a couple weeks at least I suspect.

author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 launch will have 2x.  Changing it when under attack would require another hard fork after that.

content: So after the merge miners will decide to continue mining a ETH 1.x chain right? And as soon EIP1559 comes out they will opt to mine a chain that doesn't support it - correct? I'm wondering why nobody is mining a chain with the old 5 ETH block reward as we speak... as you said - miners are the only stakeholders who matter. And this never ending spam in a research channel when you lads clearly haven't even read the spec is really the icing on the cake.

author: misterx7348
content: Ah I see. That may still be a problem then I suppose. What other effects does the elasticity multiplier have?

author: sky.cactus
content: Maximum throughput over a short period.  And some minor things with base fee rate of change I think.

author: misterx7348
content: Alright

author: misterx7348
content: It indeed boils down to "muh fee revenue" to miners.

author: sky.cactus
content: I wish we had a more concrete formula for "how much should we pay per block", it would make these debates a bit more grounded.

author: misterx7348
content: Could you elaborate that a bit more?

author: sky.cactus
content:
Some people seem to think the right reward per block "enough for miners to not kick over our (Ethereum) sandcastle".  This would suggest that we are securing against attack by miners (essentially a racket).

Some people think that the right reward is enough to make a split chain attack prohibitively expensive due to cost of entering the market".

Some people think the right amount is "enough that the network can't be attacked via rented hash power".

Some people think it is "enough to make a successful double spend over `n` blocks more expensive than some arbitrary target".

author: shamuzzlik
content: Network fees are unpredictable, if EIP1559 leads to positive price action for ETH this could even be net positive for miners. With prices being more relevant for miners than the fees better not shoot your own foot here

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't have agreement on what exactly the reward is securing, so we can't agree on how much we should be paying for that security.

author: misterx7348
content: Right now even when EIP1559 is implemented, I think there will be enough hash on the network.

author: misterx7348
content: But the more hash on the network the better, so "making it enough that the network can't be attacked via rented hash power" is a bit gambling.

author: sky.cactus
content: "Enough" for what?

author: misterx7348
content: *Some people think the right amount is "enough that the network can't be attacked via rented hash power".*

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, more hashing power is better... but it also costs more and we want to minimize costs.  We *could* pay miners 1000 ETH per block and get a ton of hash power... for a bit (until the value of ETH collapsed).

author: misterx7348
content: I think ETH's price action reflects that current mining model works quite good. With price going up, more miners join the network.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe at the moment you can rent maybe 5% on the open market, potentially more on dark markets.

author: misterx7348

content: For example "normal" people in Europe/ Australia wont be able to mine ETH if current hashrate persists while fee's are cut off from miners.

author: misterx7348
content: Likely mostly ASICs and large GPU farms will persist

author: misterx7348
content: But i already said that, so wont repeat it more ðŸ˜›

author: misterx7348
content: lets say the dark markets give access to 5% as well, with that combined its 10% at current network hashrate - if the fees are cut off we go back to 1-2 years ago hashrates - the hashrate goes elsewhere / becomes available on markets to rent. Then we are likely at 20% without the new miners on the renting markets available counted yet.

author: misterx7348
content: On a 40-50% nethash drop, that becomes possibly a problem. As that hash partly will go elsewhere.

author: misterx7348
content: Nicehash/ other coins or simply quit.

author: misterx7348
content: I think the "risk" of a 51% attack becomes a factor 10x more likely. But I probably have biased reasoning anyway.

author: misterx7348
content: Normally the miners have no interest in 51% attacking a chain, as they are stakeholders that have an interest in keeping the network and its future secure.

author: misterx7348
content: But in this case, they don't care as the network will get rid of them anyway.

author: misterx7348
content: This is why BTC is so secure, with farms having dedicated mining hardware - they have an interest in keeping the chain and its future secure.

author: misterx7348
content: Im stopping the rant. ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content:
> the hashrate becomes available on markets to rent. 
This seems unlikely.  A miner won't switch to renting out their hashrate when it is unprofitable because they still have to pay for electricity.  I suppose they could run "on demand", but it seems more likely they would try to exit their position or move to anothere chain.

author: misterx7348
content: We shall see, miners like profit. Profit switching is something we've seen in BTC as well.

author: djrtwo
content:
Reminder, read the sticky in <#745072678079168654> 

> Please be civil. Please be respectful. 
> If you would feel uncomfortable saying something in person, that's a sign you shouldn't say it here.

Whenever I check on this channel, the default does not always seem to be civility and respect.
On both sides, you will not win arguments through reacting harshly to each other or piling on with short, often negative quips. That will only serve to prevent each side from being able to rationally understanding the various points at play.

Eth R&D discord has been a fantastic place for discourse. Please keep it that way.

author: mohseng
content: I call your bluff.  There won't be a contentious fork.  Let's do it.

author: timbeiko
content: Ok, so a few clarifications re: 1559 readiness

author: timbeiko
content: Personally, I **don't** think it's ready today to be put on mainnet

author: liqdmetal369
content: what bluff i am just stating the possibilities

author: timbeiko
content: First, not even all clients have an implementation. Besu has one, Geth has one (not merged) and Nethermind has one. OpenEthereum hasn't started, and no implementation is "final"

author: liqdmetal369
content: <@!291925846556540928> actually i think it has been fairly civil in here and the issue has been boiled down significantly

author: djrtwo
content: we can discuss this more in <#595721451651465227> if you want <@!199406759800995840>

author: timbeiko
content: Second, I think we're literally _this close_ (i.e. a few weeks?) to having a proper test that proves the clients can handle large blocks *with a large state*. Yes, we have data about Besu running on networks with >>>25m gas, but those don't have a mainnet-size state. Re: the poisson distribution of blocks, <@!273808422753796097> I think it could be valuable to have a short write-up explaining why it's comparable to 1559 demand spikes so we can share to AllCoreDevs. This is the #1 objection to 1559 by core devs and we should address it thoroughly IMO.

author: fire_kasina7998
content: Greedy miners going to try delay EIP-1559.

author: fire_kasina7998
content: Just watch them throw a huge tantrum.

author: timbeiko
content:
Third, 1559 will affect a lot of projects: anything that signs a transaction, deals with JSON RPC responses, etc. We don't even have the full set of EIPs for JSON RPC changes yet. I don't see a ton of value in dropping everything to do this right now when...

Fourth, Berlin is also basically done. I suspect by the time we get 2718 added (which IMO we should, otherwise even if 1559 is shipped pre-Berlin, we'll have a lot of technical debt) and the above work done, it will be shipped, so there's not a ton of value in derailing the process to push 1559.

author: liqdmetal369
content: <@!772454146766536719> surely we should reduce rewards such that only china affordably mines, it will do wonders for centralization

author: timbeiko
content: Re: miners' comments, I agree they are very disruptive to this channel. Not sure what the best way is to capture/address them? Should we have #1559-mining? It's also worth noting that while the comments are disruptive to the chat, they haven't slowed down the development of 1559 at all.

author: .vbuterin
content: I definitely think that this channel is at this point not the appropriate venue for the "should it happen?" governance debate. EIP 1559 has economic consequences, and we already have a community precedent that EIPs with economic consequences get escalated beyond the core dev-focused forums, and furthermore we've already had lots of discussion and signaling in other forums.

author: timbeiko
content: We have a v1 of 1559 that's implemented in Besu + Nethermind + a fork of Geth. The implementations have the entire 1559 mechansism done, but they don't have the "polishing" to make it work smoothly throught the client, i.e. getting a JSON RPC response for a 1559-style transaction, block, etc.

author: timbeiko
content: Yeah, I think if people have a legit disagreement or point they want to make, they should try and write up something and either share it here or on the EthMagicians thread, but not have the entire conversation here ðŸ‘

author: timbeiko
content: This doesn't 100% depend on me, but I believe a realistic timeline is something like: next ACD or two we set the blocks, which are a few weeks away on testnets and longer away on mainnet. I suspect it should be live by the end of Q1. That means if we wanted to have a more targetted fork for 1559, it could very likely be sometime in the summer.
